title: Police algorithm said Lina was at 'medium' risk. Then she was killed

titles: Police algorithm said Lina was at 'medium' risk. Then she was killed
summary: Spanish police have implemented an algorithm designed to evaluate the likelihood of repeat incidents in domestic violence cases. This tool aids in assessing the risk level to manage and prevent future occurrences effectively. The current status or effectiveness of this algorithm in reducing repeat cases of domestic violence has not been explicitly reported.

titles: India's sword-wielding grandmother still going strong at 82
summary: At 82 years old, Meenakshi Amma is recognized as possibly the oldest woman to practice an ancient Indian martial art. Her dedication and skill in this traditional form of combat highlight her unique position in the martial arts world, demonstrating that age is not a barrier to pursuing and excelling in physical disciplines.

title: US Supreme Court halts deportation of detained Venezuelans
snippets: The accused gang members are being sent to a notorious jail in El Salvador under a 19th-Century law.
titles: US Supreme Court halts deportation of detained Venezuelans
summary: In El Salvador, accused gang members are being transferred to a notorious prison as part of a crackdown on gang activity. This move is facilitated by a law dating back to the 19th century, which the government is utilizing to combat the gangs.

title: Inside Elon Musk's government-subsidised Texas headquarters
snippets: The tycoon and Donald Trump advisor has moved his businesses from California to a mostly rural central Texas county. What do the neighbours think?
titles: Inside Elon Musk's government-subsidised Texas headquarters
summary: A tycoon and advisor to Donald Trump has relocated his businesses from California to a predominantly rural county in central Texas. The move has sparked curiosity and a range of reactions among the local residents in the new location.

title: Frustration follows yet another season after Sabres extend NHL-record playoff drought to 14 years
snippets: There were no feelings of satisfaction on Saturday, unlike the ones Sabres general manager Kevyn Adams expressed two years ago when Buffalo showed signs of progress in finishing a mere two points out of playoff contention.  All that was left was frustration, with Adams fixing the blame on himself after the Sabres extended their NHL-record playoff drought to a 14th season, and some 18 months after he had declared the team’s competitive window being open.
titles: Frustration follows yet another season after Sabres extend NHL-record playoff drought to 14 years
summary: Buffalo Sabres General Manager Kevyn Adams expressed frustration as the team missed the playoffs for the 14th consecutive season, setting an NHL record for the longest playoff drought. This comes 18 months after Adams declared the team's competitive window open, contrasting the optimism seen two years ago when the Sabres were close to playoff contention. Adams took responsibility for the team's continued struggles.

title: Everything Sherrone Moore said post-spring game

But, you know, all in all, I just wanted to see everybody have fun, injury-free football game, and that's what we got accomplished.
titles: Everything Sherrone Moore said post-spring game
summary: Trevor McCue commented on the blue team's performance, highlighting their overall good play despite some penalties. He emphasized the importance of having a fun, injury-free football game, which was achieved.

title: What are the biggest questions for the Boston Celtics series against the Orlando Magic?
snippets: What are the biggest questions for when the Boston Celtics and Orlando Magic face off on April 20?
titles: What are the biggest questions for the Boston Celtics series against the Orlando Magic?
summary: The key focus for the upcoming game between the Boston Celtics and Orlando Magic on April 20 revolves around several strategic and performance-based questions. These include the health and readiness of key players, defensive strategies both teams will employ, how each team plans to leverage their star players, adjustments from previous matchups, and the impact of bench players. The outcome of this game will be significantly influenced by how effectively each team addresses these areas.

title: Ukraine says Russian attacks continue after Putin declares ceasefire
snippets: Sirens sound in Kyiv as air defences open fire on incoming missiles minutes after announcement
titles: Ukraine says Russian attacks continue after Putin declares ceasefire
summary: Sirens were activated in Kyiv, signaling an air raid as the city's air defenses engaged incoming missiles. This action occurred minutes after an official announcement was made, indicating a prompt response to the threat. The current status of the missile interception or any potential damages has not been specified.

title: US and Iran agree to another round of talks to end nuclear stand-off
snippets: Adversaries will meet in Oman next week after ‘forward-looking’ negotiations in Rome
titles: US and Iran agree to another round of talks to end nuclear stand-off
summary: Adversaries have agreed to meet in Oman next week following constructive negotiations in Rome. The discussions in Rome were described as 'forward-looking', indicating progress towards resolving their differences. This upcoming meeting in Oman signifies a continuation of the dialogue initiated in Rome, aiming to further address and possibly reconcile the issues at hand.

title: US Supreme Court temporarily halts deportations of migrants
snippets: Justices block Trump administration’s attempt to invoke long-standing but rarely-used law
titles: US Supreme Court temporarily halts deportations of migrants
summary: The Supreme Court has stopped the Trump administration from applying a seldom-used law to a new case. This decision prevents the administration from leveraging this law, which has been on the books for years but is infrequently utilized, for their intended purposes. The outcome maintains the status quo, barring the administration from expanding the law's application as they had planned.

title: German bonds rise with euro as investors head for Europe’s haven
snippets: Fund managers say ‘breakdown’ in usual market dynamics suggests global flight to Eurozone safe asset
titles: German bonds rise with euro as investors head for Europe’s haven
summary: Fund managers have observed a 'breakdown' in typical market dynamics, indicating a global shift towards Eurozone assets considered safe. This suggests increased investor confidence in the stability of the Eurozone's financial instruments amidst market uncertainties.

title: What Analysts Think of Google Parent Alphabet's Stock Ahead of Earnings
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Google parent Alphabet plans to report first-quarter results after the market closes Thursday.
  • A majority of analysts tracked by Visible Alpha have a "buy" or equivalent rating for the stock.
  • Citi analysts said they expect Google Search would be “among the last platforms to experience macro impacts and among the first to recover.”


Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) is slated to report first-quarter results after the market closes Thursday, with analysts largely bullish on the tech giant's ability to weather economic uncertainty.

Citi analysts said recently they expect Google Search would be “among the last platforms to experience macro impacts and among the first to recover.” Citi also highlighted its potential for growth from the adoption of artificial intelligence tools like Google’s AI Mode in Search, as well as the latest iteration of the company’s Gemini large language model. 

Morgan Stanley also cited “AI-driven platform-level innovation” on Search and YouTube as a reason for “confidence in the durability of long term growth.” Citi and Morgan Stanley gave Alphabet price targets of $195 and $185, respectively. 

Of the 19 analysts covering Alphabet tracked by Visible Alpha, 14 have “buy” or equivalent ratings for the stock, with the rest issuing “hold” ratings. Their consensus price target near $195 would suggest roughly 29% upside from Thursday's closing price at about $151.

During the company's earnings call, Alphabet could face questions from analysts about a U.S. District Court ruling that Google has illegally maintained monopolies in the online advertising industry. Citi analysts said they “wouldn’t be surprised to see Google ultimately spin off its ad network,” as a result of the ruling, but that Google’s core businesses would likely not be as impacted.

Alphabet is expected to report fiscal first-quarter revenue of $89.22 billion, up 11% year-over-year, and net income of $24.71 billion, or $2.01 per share, up from $23.66 billion, or $1.89 per share, a year ago.

Shares of Alphabet have lost a fifth of their value so far in 2025 through Thursday's close. The U.S. stock market was closed Friday in observation of Good Friday.
titles: What Analysts Think of Google Parent Alphabet's Stock Ahead of Earnings
summary: Alphabet, Google's parent company, is set to report its first-quarter results after the market closes on Thursday, with analysts generally optimistic about its performance amid economic uncertainties. A majority of analysts, with 14 out of 19 tracked by Visible Alpha, recommend buying the stock, citing Google Search's resilience to macroeconomic impacts and potential growth from AI innovations. Citi and Morgan Stanley have set price targets of $195 and $185, respectively, indicating a significant upside from its current price. Analysts also anticipate discussing a recent U.S. District Court ru

title: Throwing a 'spanner in the works' of our cells' machinery could help fight cancer, fatty liver disease... and hair loss
snippets: Fifty years since its discovery, scientists have finally worked out how a molecular machine found in mitochondria, the 'powerhouses' of our cells, allows us to make the fuel we need from sugars, a process vital to all life on Earth. Scientists have worked out the structure of this machine and shown how it operates like the lock on a canal to transport pyruvate -- a molecule generated in the body from the breakdown of sugars -- into our mitochondria.
titles: Throwing a 'spanner in the works' of our cells' machinery could help fight cancer, fatty liver disease... and hair loss
summary: After fifty years of research, scientists have elucidated the structure and function of a crucial molecular machine in mitochondria, essential for converting sugars into cellular fuel. This mechanism, likened to a canal lock, facilitates the transport of pyruvate, a key molecule derived from sugar breakdown, into mitochondria, underscoring a vital process for life on Earth.

title: Turning down starlight to spot new exoplanets
snippets: Researchers have developed a new coronagraph that could make it possible to see distant exoplanets obscured by light from their parent stars.
titles: Turning down starlight to spot new exoplanets
summary: Researchers have created a new coronagraph, enhancing the ability to observe distant exoplanets by effectively reducing the glare from their parent stars. This advancement could significantly improve the study of exoplanets by making previously obscured planets visible for analysis.

title: How thoughts influence what the eyes see
snippets: A new study by biomedical engineers and neuroscientists shows that the brain's visual regions play an active role in making sense of information.
titles: How thoughts influence what the eyes see
summary: A recent study conducted by biomedical engineers and neuroscientists has found that the brain's visual regions are actively involved in interpreting information. This research highlights the significant role these areas play in processing and understanding visual data.

title: Unlocking the genetic basis of adaptive evolution: study reveals complex chromosomal rearrangements in a stick insect
snippets: Scientists report adaptive divergence in cryptic color pattern is underlain by two distinct, complex chromosomal rearrangements, where millions of bases of DNA were flipped backwards and moved from one part of a chromosome to another, independently in populations of stick insects on different mountains.
titles: Unlocking the genetic basis of adaptive evolution: study reveals complex chromosomal rearrangements in a stick insect
summary: Scientists have discovered that in stick insects from different mountains, adaptive divergence in their cryptic color patterns is caused by two unique, complex chromosomal rearrangements. These genetic modifications involve the flipping and relocation of millions of DNA bases within chromosomes, occurring independently in each insect population. This finding highlights the intricate genetic mechanisms behind the evolution of camouflage in these insects.
